target_title: Draft: Allow declaring a symbol as not a method

note.body: Moving the newly introduced warnings to strict mode sounds like a good plan.

target_title: Draft: Allow declaring a symbol as not a method

note.body:
At this point, adding `(not method)` is not enough, because it will change **a lot** of API in existing bindings and code bases.

We *really* want to have annotations on instance parameters, like `(nullable)`, because we use them to generate the C documentation; but language bindings will have to handle it in a custom way:

1. `g_main_context_invoke(null, callback, data)` is **not** equal to `main_context?.invoke(() => { data })` in JavaScript, for instance, because a `NULL` main context means "use the default global main context", whereas the `?.` operator in JS means "short circuit if main_context is null`
2. same for `gsk_transform_rotate(null, angle)` being different from `transform?.rotate(angle)`
3. on the other hand, `g_cancellable_cancel(null)` is exactly what `cancellable?.cancel()` provides: null-safety

We really don't want to turn every call site of `gsk_transform_rotate()` into `Gsk::Transform::rotate()` just because there's some C convenience sugar around `NULL` transform objects.

My plan is, at this moment, to move all the newly introduced warnings to "strict" mode and basically return to the [status quo ante](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Latin_phrases_(S)#status_quo_ante), and then figure out a way to generate a full diagnostic for these kinds of C traps in our API.

Adding `not method` can still be on the table, but it won't solve this particular issue.

target_title: Draft: Allow declaring a symbol as not a method

Inlined functions should be skipped

note.body:
This works now. There is an example in the test suite and it appears like this in the GIR:
```xml
      <method-inline name="inline_method"
                     c:identifier="regress_test_obj_inline_method"
                     introspectable="0">
        <source-position filename="regress.h" line="1720"/>
        <return-value transfer-ownership="none">
          <type name="gboolean" c:type="gboolean"/>
        </return-value>
        <parameters>
          <instance-parameter name="obj" transfer-ownership="none">
            <type name="TestObj" c:type="RegressTestObj*"/>
          </instance-parameter>
          <parameter name="foo" transfer-ownership="none">
            <type name="gboolean" c:type="gboolean"/>
          </parameter>
        </parameters>
      </method-inline>
```

target_title: Add some warnings and errors validating the annotations on methods' instance parameter

note.body:
> Instance parameter shouldn't be nullable; some existing libraries already did this, so make it a warning

This should probably be a strict mode warning, otherwise libraries will not be able to build without warnings; unlike compiler warnings, introspection operates on the public API, which means there are various cases in which you can't fix warnings/errors without breaking API.

The other two diagnostic messages are fine.

target_title: Ability to add annotation for zero-terminated array types

note.body: I hit this problem just now while porting resynthesizer's python plugin to 3.0. I was trying to pass an array of drawables to a C procedure from a Python procedure, but there didn't seem to be a way to convert a python array to a null terminated c array. Should I be using [ProcedureConfig.set_core_object_array](https://developer.gimp.org/api/3.0/libgimp/method.ProcedureConfig.set_core_object_array.html)here?

target_title: Ability to add annotation for zero-terminated array types

note.body:
We don't have this kind of type annotation, at the moment: annotations are meant to be used for arguments, partially because "zero terminated" is just one of the characteristic of an array. You can't have an array type with a fixed size, or with a parametrised length. Additionally, this kind of information is not available at the type system level: you can't really register a type `A<T>`, or a type like `A<T; const N: size_t>`.

In practice, all these types are just boxed types: you get to provide a wrapper API to add/remove/list the contents of the container. If you want to make it more idiomatic with a language, you have to provide your own binding override for the type.

note.body:
I meant the entire "Projects using GObject-introspection" and "Projects that could use GObject-introspection" sections.
(Sorry for the delay in replying.)

I think they were probably written when GObject-introspection was quite new and needed to convince projects to move from the old hand-maintained language bindings to the new generated ones. That hasn't been relevant for a decade now.

target_title: Ability to add annotation for zero-terminated array types

note.body:
For info, I encountered further of this issue and have to create various binding-only workaround functions to handle all boxed array types I am creating. Here is a list of functions failing:

* `g_object_set_property()`, with a NULL-terminated array of objects but since the binding don't know that this is what it is, it can't convert from the native array/list type to C-array. For instance, in Python, I'd expect to be able to call:

```py
>>> config.set_property('drawables', [layer1, layers2]))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: could not convert [<Gimp.Layer object at 0x7f75d6f2e340 (GimpLayer at 0x5576aa7bd130)>, <Gimp.Layer object at 0x7f75d5f9bc00 (GimpLayer at 0x5576aa7d8150)>] to type 'GimpCoreObjectArray' when setting property 'GimpProcedureConfig-script-fu-add-bevel.drawables'
```

* `gobject_get_property()` for the same reason:

```py
>>> config.get_property('drawables')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'gobject.GBoxed' object has no attribute '__module__'. Did you mean: '__reduce__'?
```

* And any function returning a `GValue`, in some bindings (e.g. pygobject), they try to be clever by transforming automatically the GValue into the contained value. This works for boxed values to struct, but not boxed values to array types. The binding doesn't know how to process it. If we could just add some annotation like suggested above, the binding would have the information to transform the C null-terminated array into the native array type, and back.

* I assume that in a binding when they return the `GValue` type, then `g_value_get_boxed()` would fail too on such array type, for the same reason as the above point.

bitfields seem limited to 32 bits width

note.body: As I said, the problem is not just limited to introspection: it's the whole type system. You'd have a very bad day if you tried using those enumeration values for GObject properties or signals, for instance.

target_title: bitfields seem limited to 32 bits width

note.body:
> that at least should allow us to use the fields from python, no?

No, it would very much not. You'd have `Foo.BarEnum.VALUE` and `Foo.BAR_ENUM_VALUE`, with zero type checking or association between the value and the enumeration. On top of that, you'd break every other language binding.

target_title: bitfields seem limited to 32 bits width

note.body: That sounds like it would open up a world of confusion and pain in the future. A constant is not a bitfield (enum/flags type) value in the eyes of the type system.

target_title: bitfields seem limited to 32 bits width

note.body: Maybe a stupid question, but could the enums with the > 32 bit values be stored as `constant`s rather than `bitfield`s? i.e. `<type name="guint64"...` -- that at least should allow us to use the fields from python, no?

target_title: bitfields seem limited to 32 bits width

note.body: Yep, that's a good idea; we already have strictness warnings for enumeration names starting with a number, adding one for size would be easy.

target_title: bitfields seem limited to 32 bits width

note.body: We probably could warn when generating or compiling a GIR file with a enum/flags value which is too big though.

target_title: bitfields seem limited to 32 bits width

note.body: Sadly, we cannot change the typelib data format without breaking every single binding and requiring all downstreams to carry two separate typelib packages for every library. On top of that, we also can't change `GEnum`/`GFlags` without breaking GLib's ABI, or deprecating a whole lot of code.

target_title: bitfields seem limited to 32 bits width

note.body: Yes, this is a known limitation of `GFlags` types (and C enumerations having an undefined size outside of its minimum), not just introspection: values in a `GFlags` type are stored as an `unsigned long` and capped at `G_MAXUINT`, so you cannot rely on it being able to express 64 bit values across all platforms. See: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/issues/617

target_title: bitfields seem limited to 32 bits width

note.body: My guess would be that the value is limited to that size in the typelib file, and it [looks like it is limited to `int32_t`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/main/girepository/gitypelib-internal.h?ref_type=heads#L798).

target_title: bitfields seem limited to 32 bits width
